channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Eight Israeli Arab Men Charged With Aiding ISIS
item.description: The men, residents of Galilee and the Negev desert, have been charged with membership and activity in the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Marine Le Pen: France Was Attacked by Islamic Fundamentalism
item.description: Islamist terrorism is a cancer on Islam, and Muslims must fight it at our side.
item.dc:creator: By MARINE LE PEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Human Rights and the 2022 Olympics
item.description: New reforms will get a rigorous test as Kazakhstan and China vie for the title.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MINKY WORDEN

item.title: Elena Obraztsova, Jewel of the Bolshoi Opera, Is Dead at 75
item.description: Ms. Obraztsova, a mezzo-soprano, survived the siege of Leningrad to become one of the Soviet Union’s greatest opera singers with theatrical triumphs around the world.
item.dc:creator: By SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY
item.media:description: Elena Obraztsova in her 1976 Metropolitan Opera debut, playing Amneris in "Aida."

item.title: Anti-Immigrant Rally Canceled in Germany After Leader Is Threatened
item.description: Pegida, whose weekly rallies in Dresden have attracted as many as 25,000 people, called off Monday’s rally, citing a terrorist threat to its leader.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Prominent North Korean Defector Recants Parts of His Story
item.description: Shin Dong-hyuk became famous after speaking about his childhood in a prison camp. On Sunday, he said that elements of his harrowing tale were untrue.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Francis Addresses Poverty at Mass in Manila
item.description: The pope’s final Mass of his Asian tour also touched on the subject of the environment and drew millions.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY and AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: News Analysis: For Indonesians, President’s Political Outsider Status Loses Its Luster
item.description: The Indonesian president’s appointments have cast doubt on his reputation as a man of the people and his promises of a squeaky-clean government.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Two months into his term, President Joko Widodo of Indonesia, center, met with families of AirAsia Flight 8501 passengers.

item.title: A Multiethnic Movement Emerges in Guyana to Counter Politics-as-Usual
item.description: A few years ago, a gathering of members of Guyana’s two main ethnic groups — descendants of African slaves and indentured laborers from India — would have been unusual, but a new third party has changed that dynamic.
item.dc:creator: By GIRISH GUPTA

item.title: U.S. Lawmakers in Cuba for 3-Day Visit
item.description: The delegation, led by Senator Patrick Leahy, will discuss with Cuban officials greater cooperation and remaining areas of disagreement. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York is also planning a trip.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and SUSANNE CRAIG

item.title: Islamic State Frees 350 Elderly and Ailing Yazidis
item.description: The Islamic State freed about 350 members of Iraq’s Yazidi minority on Saturday, delivering them to safety in the country’s northern Kurdish region.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Anchor Leaves CNN After Tweets
item.description: Jim Clancy, who was at the cable news network for more than 30 years, left after controversy flared around a series of Twitter posts he made.
item.dc:creator: By EMILY STEEL

item.title: Belgium Deploys Troops After Foiling Possible Plot
item.description: Beefing up security around Jewish sites, embassies and other potential terrorist targets, Belgium deployed scores of heavily armed paratroopers on Saturday in Brussels and Antwerp.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Houthi Rebels Abduct Aide to Yemen’s President
item.description: Shiite Houthi rebels abducted the office director for Yemen’s president on Saturday in the capital in an effort to disrupt a meeting on a new constitution, which includes provisions to which the Houthis have strongly objected.
item.dc:creator: By SHUAIB ALMOSAWA

item.title: Boat Accident in East China Kills 22 People
item.description: Chinese authorities confirmed that 22 people on the test voyage of a tugboat on the Yangtze River had died.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Churches Burn in Niger as Muslim Rally Is Banned
item.description: After the authorities banned a meeting called by local Muslim leaders to protest cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad, protesters in Niger’s capital set fire to police vehicles and at least two Catholic churches.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: A police vehicle was set on fire in front of the grand mosque in Niamey, Niger, and tear gas was used to disperse demonstrators.

item.title: Morocco Crushed Dissent Using a U.S. Interrogation Site, Rights Advocates Say
item.description: The authorities in Morocco denied allegations that they used the war against terrorism and harsh C.I.A. tactics as a cover to torture those who spoke out against them.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AIDA ALAMI

item.title: Chérif and Saïd Kouachi’s Path to Paris Attack at Charlie Hebdo
item.description: Documents reveal how Chérif Kouachi became a professional jihadist virtually under the noses of the French authorities and, with his brother, Saïd, carried out the attack on Charlie Hebdo.
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: The Paris newsroom of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, after two brothers walked in with military precision and killed 12 people in the name of Allah.

item.title: Sunnis in Iraq Are Kept Waiting for Reforms, and Word on Loved Ones
item.description: Promises of judicial reforms have gone largely unfulfilled, while practices adopted by the United States after the invasion in 2003 remain at the core of Sunni grievances.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunni women waited for information about family members at Baghdad’s main judicial complex. Promises of judicial reforms in Iraq have gone largely unfulfilled.

item.title: A Grass-Roots Pitch in Greece Could Pay Off
item.description: Greece under Alexis Tsipras would likely take a sharp turn from its direction of the past five years, when it has adhered to European insistence on austerity in return for aid.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alexis Tsipras, the leader of the Syriza Party in Greece, is more polished than when he first came to prominence in 2012. Polls suggest the party is likely to control the next government.
